title.narrative: A Cash for Work Initiative in support of the introduction and adoption of Zaï practises, complementeci by Cash Transfers for households “in crisis“ during the lean season

description.narrative: The BRES-CFFEWP project (BRACED) of the Welthungerhilfe consortium does not have any contingency fund or any specific activity to deal with emergencies, and to manage disasters or slow onset crises. PHASE funding would therefore provide the opportunity to mitigate negative effects associated with slow onset fond insecurity in the project area, whilst the consortium is still working on strengthening farmers‘ adaptive capacity. In practical terms Welthungerhilfe envisages doing so through a Cash for Work initiative in support of the introduction of Zaï and composting practices by project beneficiaries in the run-up to the rainy season and through unconditional cash transfers to the most vulnerable people (both project beneficiaries and non-beneficiaries) during the lean season.

The intervention seeks to provide Cash for Work in support of the implementation of Zaï practices on degraded land between 2,610 and 3,730 beneficiary households in 87 villages of the Kourwéogo province (representing approximately 25,000 to 36,180 persons, of whom 53% are women), aiming to apply Zaï practices an 1,800 to 2,610 ha of land in the Kourwéogo province. Secondly the intervention will support a maximum of 1,000 households “in crisis“ (representing approximately 10,000 persons of whom 53% women) with a non-conditional cash transfer during the lean season (June to August 2017).
